title: R Handbook
text:
This handbook is a reference companion for your Research Methods labs. Use it to look up R code patterns when you‚Äôre working on assignments.






TipHow to Use




Search (Ctrl/Cmd + F) for what you need
Copy code examples and adapt them
Bookmark this page for quick access

title: R Handbook
text:
2.1 Assignment and Objects

# Assign a value to a variable
x <- 5
my_score <- 42

# View a variable
x
print(my_score)

# Remove a variable
rm(x)

# List all objects in environment
ls()

title: R Handbook
text:
2.2 Data Types

# Numeric
age <- 25
height <- 1.75

# Character (text)
name <- "Alice"
group <- "control"

# Logical (TRUE/FALSE)
passed <- TRUE
is_control <- FALSE

# Check type
class(age)        # "numeric"
class(name)       # "character"
class(passed)     # "logical"

title: R Handbook
text:
2.3 Vectors

# Create a vector with c()
scores <- c(4, 5, 3, 2, 5)
names <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol")
conditions <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)

# Access elements
scores[1]         # First element: 4
scores[2:4]       # Elements 2 through 4
scores[c(1, 3)]   # Elements 1 and 3

# Useful functions
length(scores)    # Number of elements
sum(scores)       # Sum of all elements
mean(scores)      # Average
min(scores)       # Minimum
max(scores)       # Maximum

title: R Handbook
text:
2.4 Basic Operations

# Arithmetic
5 + 3     # Addition
10 - 4    # Subtraction
6 * 7     # Multiplication
20 / 4    # Division
2 ^ 3     # Exponent (2 cubed = 8)
17 %% 5   # Modulo (remainder: 2)

# Comparisons (return TRUE/FALSE)
5 > 3     # Greater than
5 < 3     # Less than
5 == 5    # Equal to
5 != 3    # Not equal to
5 >= 5    # Greater than or equal
5 <= 3    # Less than or equal

# Logical operators
TRUE & FALSE   # AND: FALSE
TRUE | FALSE   # OR: TRUE
!TRUE          # NOT: FALSE

title: R Handbook
text:
3.1 Loading Data

# From CSV (readr package - recommended)
library(readr)
data <- read_csv("filename.csv")
data <- read_csv("path/to/filename.csv")

# From CSV (base R)
data <- read.csv("filename.csv")

# From URL
data <- read_csv("https://example.com/data.csv")

# Suppress column type messages
data <- read_csv("filename.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

title: R Handbook
text:
3.2 Inspecting Data

# First/last rows
head(data)        # First 6 rows
head(data, 10)    # First 10 rows
tail(data)        # Last 6 rows

# Structure and dimensions
str(data)         # Structure with types
dim(data)         # Rows and columns
nrow(data)        # Number of rows
ncol(data)        # Number of columns

# Column names
names(data)       # All column names
colnames(data)    # Same as names()

# Summary statistics
summary(data)     # Summary of all columns

title: R Handbook
text:
3.3 Accessing Columns

# Using $ (most common)
data$age
data$group

# Using [[ ]]
data[["age"]]

# Using [ ] with column name
data[, "age"]

# Using [ ] with column number
data[, 1]         # First column
data[, 2:4]       # Columns 2 through 4

title: R Handbook
text:
3.4 Creating New Columns

# Simple calculation
data$new_column <- data$column1 + data$column2

# With conditions
data$category <- ifelse(data$score > 50, "high", "low")

# Multiple conditions
data$grade <- case_when(
  data$score >= 70 ~ "A",
  data$score >= 60 ~ "B",
  data$score >= 50 ~ "C",
  TRUE ~ "F"
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.1 The Pipe Operator

library(dplyr)

# Pipe: |> (or %>%)
# Takes output from left, passes as first argument to right

# Without pipe
summarise(group_by(data, condition), mean = mean(score))

# With pipe (easier to read!)
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(mean = mean(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.2 Selecting Columns

# Select specific columns
data |> select(id, score, group)

# Select range of columns
data |> select(p1:p5)

# Remove columns
data |> select(-id, -notes)

# Select by pattern
data |> select(starts_with("p"))
data |> select(ends_with("score"))
data |> select(contains("time"))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.3 Filtering Rows

# Single condition
data |> filter(group == "control")
data |> filter(age > 25)

# Multiple conditions (AND)
data |> filter(group == "control", time == "pre")
data |> filter(group == "control" & time == "pre")

# Multiple conditions (OR)
data |> filter(group == "control" | group == "treatment")
data |> filter(group %in% c("control", "treatment"))

# Exclude missing values
data |> filter(!is.na(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.4 Creating/Modifying Columns

# Create new column
data |> mutate(total = p1 + p2 + p3)

# Modify existing column
data |> mutate(score = score / 100)

# Multiple operations
data |> mutate(
  total = p1 + p2 + p3,
  mean_score = total / 3,
  category = ifelse(total > 10, "high", "low")
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.5 Grouping and Summarising

# Group by one variable
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n()
  )

# Group by multiple variables
data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count observations
data |> count(condition)
data |> count(condition, time)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.6 Arranging (Sorting)

# Sort ascending
data |> arrange(score)

# Sort descending
data |> arrange(desc(score))

# Sort by multiple columns
data |> arrange(group, desc(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
5.1 Central Tendency

# Mean
mean(data$score)
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)  # Ignore missing values

# Median
median(data$score)
median(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Mode (no built-in function)
names(sort(table(data$category), decreasing = TRUE))[1]

title: R Handbook
text:
5.2 Variability

# Standard deviation
sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Variance
var(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Range
range(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
min(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
max(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Interquartile range
IQR(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
5.3 Other Useful Statistics

# Sum
sum(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Length/count
length(data$score)
n_distinct(data$id)  # Unique values (dplyr)

# Quantiles
quantile(data$score, probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75), na.rm = TRUE)

# Comprehensive summary
summary(data$score)

title: R Handbook
text:
6.1 Reverse Scoring

# For 1-5 scale: reversed = 6 - original
data$rev_item <- 6 - data$item

# For 1-7 scale: reversed = 8 - original
data$rev_item <- 8 - data$item

# For 0-4 scale: reversed = 4 - original
data$rev_item <- 4 - data$item

# General formula: reversed = (max + min) - original
# For 1-5: max + min = 6, so 6 - original

title: R Handbook
text:
6.2 Creating Scale Scores

# Sum score
data$total <- data$item1 + data$item2 + data$item3 + 
              data$rev_item4 + data$rev_item5

# Using rowSums (more efficient)
data$total <- rowSums(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3", 
                                "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                      na.rm = TRUE)

# Mean score
data$mean_score <- rowMeans(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3",
                                      "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                            na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
7.1 Basic Structure

library(ggplot2)

# Basic template
ggplot(data, aes(x = variable1, y = variable2)) +
  geom_XXXXX() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Title", x = "X Label", y = "Y Label")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.2 Histogram

# Basic histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)

# Styled histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "#4A90A4", colour = "white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Scores", x = "Score", y = "Count")

# Histogram by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, alpha = 0.6, position = "identity") +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.3 Boxplot

# Basic boxplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score)) +
  geom_boxplot()

# With fill colour
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7)

# Grouped by two variables
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Scores by Group and Time",
       x = "Group", y = "Score", fill = "Time")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.4 Bar Chart

# Counts
ggplot(data, aes(x = group)) +
  geom_bar()

# From summary data (means)
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4") +
  theme_minimal()

# With error bars
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean - se, ymax = mean + se), 
                width = 0.2) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.5 Scatterplot

# Basic scatterplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point()

# With regression line
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()

# Coloured by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score, colour = group)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.6 Customisation

# Themes
+ theme_minimal()
+ theme_classic()
+ theme_bw()

# Labels
+ labs(
    title = "Main Title",
    subtitle = "Subtitle",
    caption = "Data source",
    x = "X-axis Label",
    y = "Y-axis Label",
    fill = "Legend Title",
    colour = "Legend Title"
  )

# Colours
+ scale_fill_manual(values = c("control" = "#E8E8E8", 
                                "treatment" = "#4A90A4"))
+ scale_colour_manual(values = c("pre" = "#B8D4E3", 
                                  "post" = "#4A90A4"))

# Axis limits
+ xlim(0, 100)
+ ylim(0, 50)
+ coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100), ylim = c(0, 50))

title: R Handbook
text:
8.1 Object not found

# Error: object 'x' not found

# CAUSE: Variable does not exist
# FIX: Create it first, or check spelling

x <- 5  # Create the object
x       # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.2 Could not find function

# Error: could not find function "read_csv"

# CAUSE: Package not loaded
# FIX: Load the package first

library(readr)   # Load the package
read_csv("data.csv")  # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.3 NA result

# Getting NA when calculating statistics

# CAUSE: Missing values in data
# FIX: Add na.rm = TRUE

mean(data$score)                 # Returns NA
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)   # Returns the mean

title: R Handbook
text:
8.4 Unexpected symbol

# Error: unexpected symbol in...

# CAUSE: Usually a typo or missing comma/operator
# FIX: Check for:
#   - Missing commas between arguments
#   - Unclosed brackets or quotes
#   - Typos in function names

title: R Handbook
text:
8.5 Object of type closure

# Error: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

# CAUSE: Using a function name as if it were data
# Common with: data$column (when 'data' is the function)

# FIX: Use a different variable name
my_data <- read_csv("file.csv")
my_data$column  # Works

title: R Handbook
text:
9.1 Complete Workflow Template

# 1. Load packages
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# 2. Load data
data <- read_csv("my_data.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# 3. Inspect
head(data)
str(data)

# 4. Clean/transform
data <- data |>
  mutate(
    rev_item4 = 6 - item4,
    rev_item5 = 6 - item5,
    total = item1 + item2 + item3 + rev_item4 + rev_item5
  )

# 5. Summarise
summary_stats <- data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# 6. Visualise
ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = total, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "My Title", x = "Condition", y = "Score")

title: R Handbook
text:
9.2 Reporting Statistics in APA

# Get values
m <- mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
s <- sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
n <- sum(!is.na(data$score))

# Format for reporting
sprintf("M = %.2f, SD = %.2f", m, s)
# Output: "M = 3.45, SD = 0.89"

cat("Participants scored moderately (M =", round(m, 2), 
    ", SD =", round(s, 2), 
    ", n =", n, ")")

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Today‚Äôs Dataset
We‚Äôve collected Test Anxiety data from university students:

80 students completed the Test Anxiety Inventory
Participants in Control or Intervention groups
Anxiety measured before and after intervention
Population mean is known to be 50

Our research questions:

Does our sample differ from the population norm?
Do the groups differ at baseline and post-test?
Did anxiety change from pre to post?

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
The Five Parts



Part
Topic
Key Skills




1
Introduction
Hypotheses, test selection


2
One-Sample T-Test
t.test(x, mu = )

5
Effect Sizes & Reporting

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
What is a T-Test?
A t-test compares means to determine if differences are statistically significant.

One of the most common statistical tests in psychology
Accounts for sample size and variability
Key question: Is the observed difference larger than chance?

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
The Logic of Hypothesis Testing


Null Hypothesis (H‚ÇÄ)

States ‚Äúno effect‚Äù or ‚Äúno difference‚Äù
What we assume is true unless evidence suggests otherwise


Alternative Hypothesis (H‚ÇÅ)

States there IS an effect or difference
What we‚Äôre trying to find evidence for


We test if data provide enough evidence to reject H‚ÇÄ

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
P-Values Explained

‚ÄúIf the null hypothesis were true, what‚Äôs the probability of getting results at least this extreme?‚Äù


p < .05: Statistically significant
p ‚â• .05: Not statistically significant







Important


p < .05 doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äútrue‚Äù - it means ‚Äúunlikely if H‚ÇÄ were true‚Äù

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Three Types of T-Tests








Test
Use When
Example




One-Sample
Compare sample to known value
Is mean different from 50?


Independent
Compare two separate groups
Control vs.¬†Intervention


Paired
Compare related measurements
Before vs.¬†After

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
One-Sample T-Test
Purpose: Compare a sample mean to a known population value
\[t = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{s / \sqrt{n}}\]
Where: - \(\bar{x}\) = sample mean - \(\mu_0\) = population mean - \(s\) = sample SD - \(n\) = sample size

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
The R Code

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Reading the Output
Key values to report:

t = test statistic
df = degrees of freedom (n - 1)
p-value = probability value
95% CI = confidence interval

Decision: If p < .05, reject H‚ÇÄ

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Independent Samples T-Test
Purpose: Compare means of two different groups
\[t = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{SE_{difference}}\]

Welch‚Äôs test (default): Does NOT assume equal variances
Student‚Äôs test: Assumes equal variances

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
The R Code

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
The Formula Syntax
t.test(outcome ~ grouping_variable, data = dataframe)
This reads: ‚ÄúTest if outcome differs by group‚Äù
Examples: - anxiety_post ~ group - exam_score ~ condition - reaction_time ~ treatment

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Paired Samples T-Test
Purpose: Compare two related measurements from same people
\[t = \frac{\bar{d}}{s_d / \sqrt{n}}\]

Tests if mean difference ‚â† 0
More powerful than independent t-test
Each person is their own control

Why Effect Sizes Matter



Study
n
Difference
p-value
Cohen‚Äôs d




A
1000
1.5 points
p < .001
0.10

30
8.0 points

P-values tell us IF. Effect sizes tell us HOW BIG.

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
Cohen‚Äôs d
\[d = \frac{\text{Difference}}{\text{Standard Deviation}}\]
Cohen‚Äôs conventions:



d
Interpretation




0.2
Small


0.5
Medium


0.8
Large

title: Lab 2: T-Tests
text:
APA Reporting Format

A paired samples t-test revealed a significant decrease in anxiety from pre-test (M = 53.20, SD = 10.15) to post-test (M = 46.82, SD = 9.45) in the intervention group, t(39) = 4.23, p < .001, d = 0.89.

Include: Descriptives, t, df, p, d

title: Plots
text:
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)



ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = score)) +
  geom_col()



ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point()



ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = score)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Troubleshooting
text:
Error: object 'x' not found
Check spelling and make sure the object exists in your environment.



Error: could not find function "read_csv"
Load the required package first: library(readr)



Error: unexpected symbol in "..."
Check for missing commas, brackets, or quotes.



# Remove NA values
data |> drop_na()

# Ignore NA in calculations
mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)
